text: copy Copy chevron-down house Home hashtag hashtag Welcome to the BOLT V2 docs Youâ€™re in the right place if you run fleets, field assets, or onâ€‘ground teams. This space helps you go from â€œwhat is BOLT?â€ to â€œship it in productionâ€. circle-info These docs are written for operators and product owners first. If youâ€™re integrating systems, start with the overview. hashtag Pick your path Iâ€™m new here â†’ get the big picture, then learn the core concepts. Iâ€™m running ops today â†’ find workflows, exceptions, and dayâ€‘toâ€‘day actions. Iâ€™m a product owner â†’ focus on roles, configuration, and KPI alignment. hashtag How to use this documentation hashtag Start with the overview Begin with the Executive Overview page to understand why BOLT V2 exists, who it serves, and the value it delivers. Use this section to align stakeholders on the mission, scope, and personas before diving into workflows. If youâ€™re on-boarding a new team, make this page part of your first-day briefing. hashtag Follow the workflows Then follow the embedded screenshots or short clips to execute with confidence. Skim the persona callouts (â€œProduct Ownerâ€, â€œOps Leadâ€, â€œConsumerâ€) so you know which steps apply to you. Each workflow page lays out: when to use it, prerequisites, step-by-step actions, and KPIs to watch. Move into the Feature Guides and Journeys collections. hashtag Follow the workflows The list doubles as a checklist when you configure the platform. hashtag Your first 15 minutes 1 hashtag Login and account setup Navigate to your dedicated URL provided by your administrator. Enter your credentials. If MFA is enabled, use the OTP you receive. If you belong to multiple organizations, select the relevant workspace. 2 hashtag Confirm visibility Open the map. Find one asset (search by name, ID, or plate). Open its details card. Confirm status and last update time. 3 hashtag Set one signal youâ€™ll monitor Pick 1 KPI or alert you care about this week. Examples: idling, speeding, geofence entry/exit, ignition on/off. Set it up and test it once. Last updated 1 month ago

title: Bolt V2 Fleet Management: End-User | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
headings: hashtag Learn more about Bolt V2
text: copy Copy chevron-down Bolt V2 Fleet Management: End-User Real-time fleet intelligence and configurable workflows that keep product owners and consumers moving in sync. What it is : Bolt is a unified operations intelligence platform for organizations that manage fleets, field assets, and on-ground personnel. It merges real-time visibility, configurable workflows, and deep reporting into a single web experience. Who itâ€™s for : Product Owners: orchestrate programs, configure roles, and align KPIs. Portal Operators: run daily operationsâ€”devices, trips, notifications, incidents, yard logistics. Public Consumers: securely access shared trackers or dock data with read-only insight. Why it matters : Reduce operational blind spots, standardize compliance, and respond faster to exceptions through location-aware dashboards, AI-assisted insights, and granular alerting. hashtag System Philosophy: Organization-First Architecture Bolt V2 has fundamentally shifted from a user-centric model to an Organization-Centric architecture . Asset Ownership: In this system, assets (vehicles, geofences, devices) are owned by an Organization , not an individual user. If a user leaves a company, the assets remain tied to the organization node. The Hierarchical Tree: Super Parent (Roadcast): The root node with "God Mode" access. Roadcast manages global plans, hardware masters, and platform-wide configurations. Parent Organization: The primary client entity (e.g., a logistics company). Child Branches: Sub-entities or regional offices that inherit settings from the Parent but can maintain operational isolation. hashtag The Organization Tree The structure of Bolt V2 is built as a recursive tree, ensuring that permissions and billing can be managed at scale. Structure Hierarchy: Level 0: Roadcast (The Root) Access : Platform Administration. Responsibility : Creating standard plans, onboarding enterprise clients, and managing hardware masters (IMEIs, SIMs). Level 1: Enterprise Parent (Client Level) Access : Organization Admin. Responsibility : Managing the master wallet, creating internal user roles, and configuring global geofences. Level 2: Child Branches / Regional Hubs Access : Branch Manager / Operations. Responsibility : Day-to-day dispatch, yard management, and driver assignments. Inheritance Logic: Permissions: Roles created at the Parent level are automatically available to all Child branches. Data Visibility: Parents can view all data from their Children; however, a Child branch is isolated and cannot see sibling or parent data. Billing: If an organization is created without a designated parent, it is automatically nested directly under the Roadcast root. hashtag Learn more about Bolt V2 #insert video Next Getting Started chevron-right Last updated 1 month ago
excerpt: copy Copy chevron-down Bolt V2 Fleet Management: End-User Real-time fleet intelligence and configurable workflows that keep product owners and consumers moving in sync. What it is : Bolt is a unified operations intelligence platform for organizations that manage fleets, field assets, and on-ground personnel. It merges real-time visibility, configurable workflows, and deep reporting into a single web experience. Who itâ€™s for : Product Owners: orchestrate programs, configure roles, and align KPIs.

title: Getting Started | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
headings: hashtag Scenario A: You are a New Fleet Administrator
hashtag Scenario B: You are an Invited User
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs Getting Started Because a single user can be a member of multiple organizations, the Select Organisation screen appears immediately after login. hashtag 1. System Requirements To ensure the best experience, please use one of the following supported web browsers: Google Chrome (Recommended) Mozilla Firefox Microsoft Edge Safari Note: Please ensure your browser is up to date. Internet Explorer is not supported. hashtag 2. The "First-Time" Experience What you see upon your first login depends on your role and the status of your organization. hashtag Scenario A: You are a New Fleet Administrator If you are the first person logging into a brand-new organization, you will be greeted by the Onboarding Wizard. This is a guided setup designed to get your operations running in minutes. You will be asked to: Add Your First Vehicle: Enter the registration number and IMEI of your GPS device. Create a Group: Organize your fleet (e.g., "North Zone" or "Heavy Trucks") to manage permissions easily. Invite Team Members: Add email addresses for your dispatchers or managers so they can access the platform. Tip: You can skip these steps and complete them later in Settings, but we recommend adding at least one vehicle to enable the Dashboard view. hashtag Scenario B: You are an Invited User If you were invited to an existing organization, you will land directly on the Live Dashboard. Map View: You will see all vehicles assigned to you plotted on the map. Status Indicators: Vehicles are color-coded (Green for Moving, Red for Stopped, Grey for Inactive). hashtag 3. Navigating the Workspace The Bolt V2 interface is divided into three main areas: hashtag A. The Sidebar (Main Menu) Located on the left, this is your primary navigation tool. Dashboard: Real-time overview of fleet statistics. Live Tracking: Detailed map view with vehicle controls. Reports: Access history, mileage, and trip logs. Yard Management: (If enabled) Manage dock and warehouse operations. Settings: Configure alerts, geofences, and user profiles. hashtag B. The Top Bar Global Search: Quickly find a vehicle by name, tag, or IMEI. Notifications (Bell Icon): View critical alerts like overspeeding or geofence breaches. Profile Menu: Access your account settings and logout. hashtag 4. Personalizing Your Account Before you start tracking, we recommend setting up your preferences. Navigate to Settings > Profile. Language: Select your preferred language (English or Hindi). Security: Update your password if you are using a temporary one provided by your admin. Notifications: Choose whether you want alerts via Email, SMS, or Mobile App Push Notifications. hashtag 5. Next Steps Now that you are set up, where would you like to go? Learn how to Track Vehicles arrow-up-right Generate your first Report arrow-up-right Manage Users & Permissions arrow-up-right Previous Bolt V2 Fleet Management: End-User chevron-left Next Account Setup & Login chevron-right Last updated 1 month ago

title: Fleet Operations | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs Fleet Operations The Fleet Operations module allows you to onboard new vehicles, manage driver profiles, and organize your fleet into logical groups. Unlike "Live Tracking" (which is for monitoring), this area is for hashtag 1. Vehicle Management To view your fleet list, navigate to Management Hub > Vehicles in the sidebar. hashtag The Vehicle List The main table displays all assets currently active in your account. Search: Use the top bar to find vehicles by Registration Number, IMEI, or Driver Name. Filters: Filter by Status (Active/Inactive) or Group . Actions: âœï¸ Edit: Update vehicle details (e.g., Change Model, Update Registration). ðŸ”— Link Device: Assign a new GPS tracker (IMEI) to an existing vehicle profile. ðŸ—‘ï¸ Deactivate: Remove a vehicle from your subscription (stops billing). hashtag Adding a New Vehicle Click the "+ Add Vehicle" button. Step 1: Device Setup Enter the IMEI (15-digit serial number) of your GPS device. Select the Device Model from the dropdown. Step 2: Vehicle Details Enter the Registration Number (License Plate). Select Vehicle Type (Truck, Car, Bike, etc.) for correct icon representation on the map. Step 3: Assignment (Optional) Assign a Driver immediately. Select a Group (e.g., "North Zone") to ensure the right managers can see it. hashtag 2. Driver Management Navigate to Management Hub > Drivers to maintain a digital database of your staff. hashtag Creating a Driver Profile Click "Add Driver". Personal Details: Name, Phone Number (used for login if enabled), and Employee ID. License Info: Upload a photo of the Driving License and enter the expiry date. Note: The system can trigger alerts when a license is nearing expiry. RFID/iButton: If your vehicles use Driver ID sensors, enter the tag ID here to auto-assign drivers to trips. hashtag Assigning Drivers to Vehicles Manual Assignment: Go to the Vehicle List, click "Edit", and select a driver. Auto-Assignment: If using RFID tags, the driver is automatically assigned to the vehicle when they swipe their card in the cabin. hashtag 3. Grouping & Organization Groups allow you to segment your fleet so that specific managers only see relevant vehicles. Navigate to: Settings > Device Groups. Create Group: Name it (e.g., "Heavy Haulage" or "Mumbai Branch"). Assign Assets: Select multiple vehicles and move them into the group. Permissions: When inviting a new Sub-User (Dispatcher), you can restrict their view to only specific groups. hashtag 4. Maintenance & Documents Keep your fleet compliant by uploading digital records. hashtag Document Locker For every vehicle or driver, you can upload: RC (Registration Certificate) Insurance Papers PUC (Pollution Certificate) Permits To Upload: Select the Vehicle/Driver. Go to the "Documents" tab. Click "Upload" and set an Expiry Date. Benefit: Bolt V2 will send you a reminder notification 30 days before any document expires. hashtag Frequently Asked Questions Q: I added a vehicle, but it's not on the map. A: Ensure the device is powered on and has a valid SIM card. New devices may take up to 15 minutes to sync for the first time. Q: Can one vehicle belong to multiple groups? A: No, a vehicle can typically belong to only one primary reporting group to prevent permission conflicts. Q: How do I swap a GPS device from one truck to another? A: Go to Vehicle > Edit > Unlink Device. Then, go to the new vehicle and select Link Device, entering the same IMEI. Previous Troubleshooting chevron-left Next Live Tracking & Remote Operations chevron-right Last updated 13 days ago

title: Administration | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs Administration The Administration module is the control center of your Bolt V2 workspace. It provides the tools necessary to manage your organization's hierarchy, secure your data through permissions, and handle financial operations. Designed for Fleet Managers and System Administrators, this section covers the setup and maintenance of your digital workforce. hashtag In this section Feature Description User Management & Governance arrow-up-right Learn how to invite team members, configure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), and define exactly what each user can see and do within the platform. Billing & Wallet Logic arrow-up-right A complete guide to the Enterprise Wallet system. Understand how credits work, how trips are billed, and how to top up your account to prevent service interruptions. hashtag Key Administrative Capabilities User Provisioning: Create, edit, and suspend user accounts instantly. Permission Control: Assign pre-built roles (e.g., "Viewer", "Manager") or create custom permission sets. Financial Oversight: Monitor daily deductions, view transaction logs, and download invoices. Audit Logging: Track "Who did what and when" for security and compliance. Previous Reports & Analytics chevron-left Next Administration & Governance chevron-right Last updated 13 days ago

title: Account Setup & Login | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
headings: hashtag Method B: Login with OTP (One-Time Password)
hashtag Step 3: Admin Onboarding (The "Get Started" Wizard)
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Getting Started Account Setup & Login This guide explains how to access the Bolt V2 Portal, log in securely, and manage your account credentials. hashtag 1. Accessing the Portal hashtag A. New Organizations (Fleet Owners) If you are a new client looking to set up a workspace for your company: Provisioning: New organizations are created exclusively by the Roadcast Support Team. Activation: Once your workspace is ready, you will receive a "Welcome" email with your login credentials and a verification link. Request Access: To start a new organization, please contact your Account Manager or email support@roadcast.in . hashtag B. Team Members (Dispatchers & Managers) If you are joining an existing fleet: Invitation: Your Fleet Administrator must add you to the system. Notification: You will receive an email or SMS containing your username and a link to set your password. hashtag 2. Logging In The login screen supports multiple authentication methods to ensure security. hashtag Method A: Password Login (Standard) Enter Username: Input your registered Email Address or Mobile Number. Enter Password: Type your secure password. Tip: Click the "Eye" icon to toggle password visibility if you are unsure what you typed. Submit: Click the "Login" button. hashtag Method B: Login with OTP (One-Time Password) If you do not remember your password or prefer a password-less login: Enter your Mobile Number or Email on the login screen. Click "Login with OTP" (or "Get OTP"). Check your device: You will receive a verification code via SMS or Email. Enter Code: Input the code in the OTP Verification screen. Click "Verify" to access your dashboard. hashtag 3. First-Time Setup Steps When logging in for the first time, the system may guide you through a few required steps. hashtag Step 1: Account Verification Screen: Verify Account Action: If your account is pending verification, you will be prompted to confirm your identity via a link sent to your registered email. hashtag Step 2: Select Organization Screen: Select Organisation Action: If your email is associated with multiple fleets (e.g., a logistics manager handling two different branches), you must select which organization you wish to view for the current session. hashtag Step 3: Admin Onboarding (The "Get Started" Wizard) Who sees this? Only Administrators of brand-new organizations. Trigger: This screen appears automatically if your organization has zero vehicles or assets. Action: The wizard will guide you to: Add Vehicles: Register your first GPS devices. Create Groups: Organize your fleet (e.g., "North Zone"). Invite Users: Add your team members. Note: Once you add your first asset, this wizard will disappear, and you will be taken directly to the Dashboard on future logins. hashtag Previous Getting Started chevron-left Next Troubleshooting chevron-right Last updated 14 days ago
excerpt: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Getting Started Account Setup & Login This guide explains how to access the Bolt V2 Portal, log in securely, and manage your account credentials. hashtag 1. Activation: Once your workspace is ready, you will receive a "Welcome" e

title: Troubleshooting | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Getting Started Troubleshooting Issue Solution "User not found" You cannot create an account yourself. Please contact your Admin to ensure they have sent the invitation to the correct email address. "Permission Denied" You have successfully logged in, but your account has no Role assigned. Contact your Admin to assign you a role (e.g., Viewer, Manager). Locked Account If you enter the wrong password too many times, your account will be locked for 15 minutes. Forgot Password Click the "Forgot Password?" link on the login screen to receive a reset link via email. Previous Account Setup & Login chevron-left Next Fleet Operations chevron-right Last updated 14 days ago

title: Live Tracking & Remote Operations | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
headings: hashtag Vehicle Marker Legend & Status Logic
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Fleet Operations Live Tracking & Remote Operations hashtag Live Tracking & Remote Operations hashtag 1. The Dashboard Layout When you click "Live Tracking" in the sidebar, you will see three main areas: The Map (Right Pane): Displays vehicle icons, geofences, and Points of Interest (POIs). The Sidebar (Left Pane): A searchable list of all assets, categorized by status. The Detail Card (Bottom/Overlay): Appears when you select a specific vehicle. hashtag 2. Navigating the Map The map is built for speed and clarity. You can customize what you see using the Layer Selector (usually top-right). Map Layers: Switch between Default (Street View), Satellite , or Hybrid . Traffic Layer: Toggle real-time traffic density (Green/Yellow/Red lines) to help route drivers around congestion. Clusters: To keep the map clean, vehicles close together are grouped into Clusters (colored circles with numbers). Action: Click a cluster to zoom in and see individual vehicles. hashtag 3. Vehicle Status & Icons Vehicles are color-coded so you can understand their status at a glance. Color Status Definition Green Running Engine is ON and vehicle is moving. Yellow Idle Engine is ON but vehicle has been stationary for over 5 minutes. Red Stopped Engine is OFF. Grey Inactive Device has not reported data for more than 24 hours (No Signal/Power Cut). hashtag 4. Monitoring a Specific Vehicle To track a single asset, find it in the sidebar list or click its icon on the map. This opens the Vehicle Detail Card, which displays: Live Metrics: Current Speed, Odometer, and Fuel Level. Location: Current address and time since last update. Sensors: (If equipped) Temperature, Door Status, or AC On/Off. hashtag Available Actions From the detail card, you can perform remote operations: ðŸ“ Playback: View the route history for today or a custom date range. ðŸ”— Share Location: Generate a temporary public link to share the vehicle's location with a customer. ðŸ›‘ Immobilize: (Authorized Admins Only) Remotely cut off the engine in case of theft. hashtag Vehicle Marker Legend & Status Logic This page defines the visual indicators used on the Live Tracking map. Use this reference to understand fleet status at a glance. Vehicle Status Colors The system color-codes markers based on real-time telematics data received from the device hardware. Status Color Hardware Condition Logic Moving Green Ignition ON + Speed > 0 Vehicle is actively performing a trip. Idle Yellow Ignition ON + Speed = 0 Engine is running but vehicle is stationary. High idling triggers "Fuel Waste" alerts. Parked Red Ignition OFF Vehicle is stationary and engine is shut down. Inactive Grey No Data > 10 Mins Device is unreachable. Check SIM data or power supply (See Troubleshooting). Vehicle Type Icons Bolt V2 utilizes distinct SVG icons to differentiate between asset classes. Asset Type Icon Description Primary Use Case Car standard sedan silhouette Passenger vehicles and executive fleet. Truck Heavy-duty logistics silhouette Cargo transport and long-haul delivery. Bike Motorcycle/Scooter silhouette Last-mile delivery and field agents. Ambulance Emergency vehicle with medical cross Critical care and emergency response units. ID Card Person/Portable tag icon Personal trackers or valuable package tracking. hashtag Advanced Map Indicators Directional Arrows: When a vehicle is moving, a small arrow appears on the marker pointing in the direction of travel (Heading). Clustering: When zoomed out, multiple vehicles in close proximity group into a "Cluster Circle" showing the total count. Click the cluster to expand. Immobilization Badge: A "Lock" icon overlay appears if the Remote Immobilization command is active (Relay is cut). hashtag Remote Commands (Immobilization) For vehicles equipped with supported hardware, operators can send remote commands: Immobilize: Remotely disables the vehicle's starter relay. This is a critical security feature used in theft recovery. Parking Mode: Create a temporary "electronic lock" around a vehicle. If the vehicle moves while this is active, high-priority alerts are sent to the Command Center. hashtag 5. Managing Zones (Geofences & POIs) The tracking screen also allows you to manage your virtual boundaries. Switch tabs in the left sidebar to view: Geofences: Polygonal zones (e.g., "Main Warehouse"). You will receive alerts when vehicles enter or exit these zones. POIs (Points of Interest): Specific markers for client locations or fuel stations. hashtag Common Questions Q: Why is a vehicle showing as "Grey/Inactive"? A: This usually means the GPS device has lost power or cellular network. Check if the vehicle is parked underground or if the device has been tampered with. Q: How fast does the map update? A: The map refreshes automatically every 10-30 seconds depending on your device's configuration. You do not need to refresh the page. Previous Fleet Operations chevron-left Next Yard & Warehouse Management chevron-right Last updated 13 days ago

title: Yard & Warehouse Management | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Fleet Operations Yard & Warehouse Management hashtag Dock & Trip Flow Optimizing turn-around time (TAT) is the primary goal of the Yard module. Trip Purpose: Every vehicle entering the facility must be assigned a purpose (e.g., Inward Goods, Outbound Dispatch, or Empty movement). Dock Activity: Track exactly how long a vehicle stays at a specific dock for loading or unloading. Approval Matrix: Custom workflows where gate-in or gate-out events require digital authorization from a supervisor. Turn-Around Time (TAT) Gauge circle-info The TAT Gauge visualizes the average Gate-to-Gate time. Green (0-60 mins): Excellent - Operations are efficient. Yellow (60-96 mins): Target - Approaching delay threshold. Red (>96 mins): Delayed - Trip requires immediate escalation. hashtag Guard View & QR Scanning A simplified, mobile-responsive interface designed for on-site security personnel. Instant Identification: Guards scan a QR code or IMEI to pull up driver profiles and trip validity. Manual Entry: Fallback option to search via vehicle registration number if hardware is not yet installed. hashtag Security & Guard Operations Guard View: A simplified, mobile-friendly interface for security guards. QR Scanning: Use the built-in scanner to quickly check-in vehicles by scanning their dashboard QR code or IMEI. Previous Live Tracking & Remote Operations chevron-left Next Reports & Analytics chevron-right Last updated 1 month ago

text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Fleet Operations Reports & Analytics hashtag Automated Reporting Turn-Around Time (TAT): Specialized reports for Yard managers to track facility efficiency. Escalation Reports: Review logs of critical events that required supervisor intervention. Custom Engine: Build your own reports by selecting specific columns, filters, and scheduling them for email delivery. hashtag AI Assistant Natural Language Queries: Use the chat interface to ask questions like "Which drivers exceeded speed limits today?" or "Show me idle vehicles in the North region." title: Administration & Governance | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Administration Administration & Governance hashtag RBAC & Permission Guardrails The platform enforces strict Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) . URL Protection: If a Client User manually types an Admin-only URL (like /admin/device-models ), the system returns a 403 Forbidden error and logs the attempt. Inheritance: Custom roles can be created at the Parent level and pushed down to all Child Branches. hashtag Impersonation & Audit Trails To assist with support and debugging, Admins have the ability to "Impersonate" users. Security Protocol: An Admin cannot change a client's password directly; they must first use the Impersonate feature. Audit Trail: Every action performed during an impersonation session is logged with a specific flag: User [Admin_ID] performed [Action] on behalf of [Client_ID] at [Timestamp] . hashtag Permission Matrix Role Live Tracking Manage Users Manage Billing Create Geofence View Reports Purchase License Admin Actions Admin âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ Dispatcher âœ”ï¸ âŒ âŒ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âŒ âŒ Guard âœ”ï¸ âŒ âŒ âŒ âŒ âŒ âŒ Manager âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ Warehouse Staff âœ”ï¸ âŒ âŒ âœ”ï¸ âŒ âŒ âŒ Financial Manager âŒ âŒ âœ”ï¸ âŒ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ âœ”ï¸ Table 1: Graph regarding the allowed actions as per role Roles are listed in the first column. Each permission (e.g., "Live Tracking," "Manage Users," etc.) is represented as a column. âœ”ï¸ indicates that the role has permission for that action, while âŒ indicates no permission. Admin Actions are actions that admins can take, like modifying permissions, managing system-wide settings, etc. hashtag Suspension Logic The "On-Trip" Case: If an Admin suspends a driver while they are currently ON_TRIP , the Driver App will log them out immediately. The session is terminated for security, and the trip state handling (auto-closing or pausing) is handed over to the TripHub backend logic. title: Billing & Enterprise Wallet Logic | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Administration Billing & Enterprise Wallet Logic The system manages financial transactions through an internal Wallet system, supporting two distinct enterprise models. hashtag Centralized Billing Model Concept: The Parent Organization acts as the "Bank." Logic: All Child Branches share a single pool of funds. Case: Even if a Child Branch has no individual budget, it can perform transactions (like license upgrades) as long as the Parent Wallet has a balance. hashtag Decentralized Billing Model Concept: Each node is a "Siloed Entity." Logic: Every Branch must maintain its own independent wallet. Case (Critical Security): If a Child Branch has a $0 balance, a purchase attempt will trigger an instant failure. The system will not fallback to the Parent Wallet, ensuring strict budget isolation between franchises or independent units. Previous Administration & Governance chevron-left Next Advanced Concepts chevron-right Last updated 1 month ago

title: UI/UX Specifications & Design System | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Advanced Concepts UI/UX Specifications & Design System This section outlines the visual standards, interaction logic, and user experience principles that define the Bolt V2 platform. hashtag Unified Design Language Bolt V2 uses a utility-first design system built on Tailwind CSS . The goal is to provide a clean, high-performance interface that prioritizes data visibility. Management Hub Approach: The interface is split into two distinct modes: Admin Side (Roadcast): Designed for high-density data management, bulk configurations, and global oversight. Client Side: Designed for operational speed, featuring simplified menus focused on tracking and day-to-day logistics. Consistency: Every page follows a standard layout: a collapsible Navigation Sidebar on the left, a Contextual Navbar at the top, and a dynamic Workspace in the center. hashtag The Contextual User Journey The most important UX principle in Bolt V2 is Organization Context . Workspace Awareness: The top navbar always displays the name of the active Organization. This is a constant visual reminder that the data being viewed is limited to that specific branch or parent. Slide-Out Workflows: To prevent "context loss," the app avoids excessive page jumping. When you click on a vehicle or trip, a Side Panel slides out from the right. This allows users to view details or edit settings while still keeping the primary map or list visible in the background. hashtag Smart Interaction Components We use a set of custom components to handle complex data entry and display tasks simply. Form Generator: Instead of hard-coded forms, Bolt V2 uses a schema-based generator. Validation: Forms provide instant feedback (e.g., matching passwords, valid IMEI formats). Requirement Indicators: Fields marked with a red asterisk are mandatory for the backend logic to process. Generic Table System: All data lists (Users, Vehicles, SIMs) use a high-performance grid. Bulk Actions: Users can select multiple rows to perform actions like "Bulk Suspension" or "Assign to Group." Skeleton Loading: While data is being fetched from the GraphQL server, the UI displays grey "shimmer" placeholders to prevent the screen from looking empty or broken. hashtag Visual Feedback & System Health The platform uses color and motion to communicate state without requiring the user to read long messages. Status Toasts: Small notification boxes appear in the corner to confirm actions: Green: Success (e.g., "License purchased successfully"). Orange: Warning (e.g., "Wallet balance is low"). Red: Error (e.g., "403: You do not have permission to view this section"). Map Marker Logic: Vehicle icons on the map use a traffic-light color system (Green/Yellow/Red/Grey) to indicate engine and connection health instantly. hashtag Hardened Security UX (PRD Case 9.3) Security is woven into the user experience through "Session Versioning" and strict access logic. Permission-Based Visibility: If a userâ€™s role does not allow "Delete" access, the delete button is completely removed from the UI, not just greyed out. This reduces clutter and prevents unauthorized attempts. Force-Logout Interaction: If an administrator suspends a user while they are logged in: The next interaction the user makes will trigger a Security Modal . The modal informs the user that their session is no longer valid. The user is automatically redirected to the Login page. Impersonation Indicators: When an Admin uses the "Impersonate" feature, the UI adopts a distinct visual highlight (often matching the clientâ€™s brand colors) to signify that the Admin is acting on behalf of a client. hashtag Mobile & Field Optimization The Guard View is a specific UX module designed for high-glare, outdoor environments. High Contrast: Large buttons and high-contrast text make it readable on mobile devices in sunlight. Integrated Scanning: The UI provides a one-tap access to the device camera for scanning QR codes, eliminating the need for manual typing of long serial numbers. Previous Advanced Concepts chevron-left Next Core Operational Logic & Expected Behaviors chevron-right Last updated 1 month ago

title: Core Operational Logic & Expected Behaviors | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Advanced Concepts Core Operational Logic & Expected Behaviors hashtag Financial & Billing Scenarios (Case 9.1) The system manages funds differently based on the organization's billing configuration. Scenario Mode Expected Behavior Financial Impact Purchase with 0 local balance Centralized Success: The system automatically identifies the Parent Wallet and deducts funds. Parent Org is charged. Purchase with 0 local balance Decentralized Failure: The transaction is blocked instantly. No charge; user must recharge. Add-on activation Either The system verifies the wallet type before initiating the Razorpay handshake. Depends on wallet mapping. hashtag Hierarchy & Permissions Scenarios (Case 9.2) Bolt V2 uses a "Safety Net" logic for organization management to ensure no data is ever lost or orphaned. Organization Assignment Flow spinner Direct URL Access Case: If a standard user attempts to bypass the navigation menu by typing a restricted URL (e.g., /admin/device-models ), the frontend interceptor checks the RBAC Store . Since the permission is missing, the system kills the request and displays a 403 Forbidden screen. hashtag Security & Session Scenarios (Case 9.3) Security protocols are hard-coded to prioritize data integrity over active sessions. The Suspension Flow: Trigger: An Admin marks a user (e.g., a Driver) as Suspended . Logic: The system updates the SessionVersion in the central database. Action: The user's current JWT (JSON Web Token) is invalidated. Result: Normal Case: The user is kicked to the login screen on their next click. On-Trip Case: The Driver App terminates the session immediately. The vehicle's active trip is handed over to the TripHub for supervisor management to prevent "Ghost Trips." hashtag Forensic Audit Pattern To maintain enterprise accountability, every sensitive action in the system is logged using a standardized forensic string. This allows for deep auditing during security reviews. Standard Log Format: User [ID] performed [ACTION] on Target [ID] at [TIMESTAMP] Impersonation Note: If an action is performed while an Admin is "Logged in as" a client, the log is appended with the [PERFORMED_BY_IMPERSONATOR] tag. This ensures that client-side changes can be traced back to administrative intervention. hashtag Enterprise Readiness & Success Criteria For large-scale enterprise deployments, the following scenarios must be validated to confirm a successful setup. Validation Area Success Scenario (Test Case) Expected System State Onboarding Full Enterprise Client Creation Admin can successfully create an Org, map Users, and assign Roles in one sequence. Financial API Automated Billing Handshake Centralized/Decentralized flows function without manual backend intervention. Security API Real-time Blacklisting Suspended users cannot make ANY API calls, even if their token has not physically expired. Data Continuity TripHub Handover Active trips continue logging data to the backend even if the driver's frontend session is killed. Enterprise Note: These criteria ensure that Bolt V2 can be handed over to a client as a "Ready-to-Use" environment. If any of these scenarios fail, the system is not considered enterprise-ready. title: Troubleshooting FAQ | Documentation | Roadcast Docs
text: copy Copy chevron-down Basic Docs chevron-right Advanced Concepts Troubleshooting FAQ Inactive Devices: If a vehicle is showing as "Inactive," first verify the "Sky View" for GPS signal. Use the built-in Troubleshoot tool to check SIM connectivity and power status. Odometer Sync: Digital odometers may drift from physical dashboard readings over time. Use the Sync Odometer feature to manually calibrate the system to match the vehicle's physical state. Service Scheduling: Set maintenance alerts based on either time intervals (e.g., 6 months) or distance intervals (e.g., 10,000 km) synced from the vehicle's odometer.
